articles.headline: Cash-Strapped Chinese Giant Taps a New Money Source: Its Workers
articles.snippet: HNA, burdened by debt after a global shopping spree, offers enticing returns to employees who invest back into the business.
articles.abstract: HNA, burdened by debt after a global shopping spree, offers enticing returns to employees who invest back into the business.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Just before payday, an email went out to employees from top executives: Give us your money, and we’ll make it worth your while.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li

articles.headline: Settlements for 3 Wall Street Banks Hold a Silver Lining
articles.snippet: Deutsche Bank, HSBC and UBS were punished for market manipulation this week — and tucked into the punishment was a single sentence that could pay big dividends for the banking industry.
articles.abstract: Deutsche Bank, HSBC and UBS were punished for market manipulation this week — and tucked into the punishment was a single sentence that could pay big dividends for the banking industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three big banks were punished for market manipulation this week — and tucked into the punishment was a single sentence that could pay big dividends for the banking industry.

articles.headline: Trump Tax Cuts and the Economy: Time Will Tell, Maybe
articles.snippet: President Trump is taking plenty of credit for positive economic signs — the stock market, jobs, growth. Is it warranted?
articles.abstract: President Trump is taking plenty of credit for positive economic signs — the stock market, jobs, growth. Is it warranted?
articles.lead_paragraph: Most presidents will at some point benefit from a surging economy and stock market, but none has claimed more credit for them than Donald J. Trump, as he did again during this week’s State of the Union address. Among the highlights:

articles.headline: Businesses Look at Washington and Say, ‘Never Mind, We’ll Do It’
articles.snippet: An effort by Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan to improve health care is the latest example of C.E.O.s trying to fill a void left by an ineffectual government.
articles.abstract: An effort by Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan to improve health care is the latest example of C.E.O.s trying to fill a void left by an ineffectual government.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can private businesses solve public policy problems better than the government? It’s a question that has persisted for decades and taken on new resonance now that a career businessman is in the White House.

articles.headline: ‘My Baby Almost Died’: Formula Scandal Sends Shudders Through France
articles.snippet: Lactalis, a giant dairy products company, has had to recall more than 7,000 tons of products contaminated with salmonella. It did not alert regulators to past problems.
articles.abstract: Lactalis, a giant dairy products company, has had to recall more than 7,000 tons of products contaminated with salmonella. It did not alert regulators to past problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — When the French dairy giant Lactalis began recalling baby formula, Ségolène Noviant thought she was safe. The milk she had been feeding her 5-month-old son wasn’t on the list.

articles.headline: With Memo, Devin Nunes, Once a Scourge of the Hard Right, Becomes Its Hero
articles.snippet: As House Intelligence Committee chairman, Representative Devin Nunes has won praise from party members he once called “lemmings in suicide vests.”
articles.abstract: As House Intelligence Committee chairman, Representative Devin Nunes has won praise from party members he once called “lemmings in suicide vests.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va. — Representative Devin Nunes once called fellow Republicans “lemmings in suicide vests.”
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: White House Wants Pentagon to Offer More Options on North Korea
articles.snippet: The Pentagon worries that the White House is moving too hastily and that giving the president too many options could increase the odds that he will act, some officials say.
articles.abstract: The Pentagon worries that the White House is moving too hastily and that giving the president too many options could increase the odds that he will act, some officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House has grown frustrated in recent weeks by what it considers the Pentagon’s reluctance to provide President Trump with options for a military strike against North Korea, according to officials, the latest sign of a deepening split in the administration over how to confront the nuclear-armed regime of Kim Jong-un.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Job and Wage Gains Deliver a Promising Start for the Year
articles.snippet: Payrolls grew by 200,000 last month and hourly earnings were up 2.9 percent in a sign that American workers were benefiting from a tight labor market.
articles.abstract: Payrolls grew by 200,000 last month and hourly earnings were up 2.9 percent in a sign that American workers were benefiting from a tight labor market.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the unemployment rate has fallen in recent months and the economy has roared, one central question has bedeviled the American job market: Where is the wage growth?

articles.headline: Making a Crypto Utopia in Puerto Rico
articles.snippet: Dozens of entrepreneurs, made newly wealthy by virtual currencies, have moved to the island to avoid taxes on their fortunes — and to build a society that runs on blockchain.
articles.abstract: Dozens of entrepreneurs, made newly wealthy by virtual currencies, have moved to the island to avoid taxes on their fortunes — and to build a society that runs on blockchain.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — They call what they are building Puertopia. But then someone told them, apparently in all seriousness, that it translates to “eternal boy playground” in Latin. So they are changing the name: They will call it Sol.

articles.headline: House Republicans Release Secret Memo Accusing Russia Investigators of Bias
articles.snippet: The memo accused senior officials at the F.B.I. and Justice Department of bias in the early stages of the Russia investigation.
articles.abstract: The memo accused senior officials at the F.B.I. and Justice Department of bias in the early stages of the Russia investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans released a politically charged memo on Friday that accused F.B.I. and Justice Department leaders of abusing their surveillance powers to spy on a former Trump campaign adviser suspected of being an agent of Russia.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos, Adam Goldman and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Yes, You Can Find a Financial Planner Even if You’re Not Rich
articles.snippet: Seeking financial assistance? You can hire advisers by the hour, by the month or based on your assets, even if you aren’t a millionaire.
articles.abstract: Seeking financial assistance? You can hire advisers by the hour, by the month or based on your assets, even if you aren’t a millionaire.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Please help me find reasonably priced financial advice from someone who won’t rob me blind.”
